references:
We implement the proposed edge-case attack in PyTorch [98].
We run experiments on p2.xlarge instances of Amazon EC2.
Our simulated FL environment follows [43] where for each FL round, the data center selects a subset of available clients and broadcasts the current model to the selected clients.
The selected clients then conduct local training for E𝐸E epochs over their local datasets and then ship model updates back to the data center. The data center then conducts model aggregation (e.g. weighted averaging in FedAvg).
The FL setups in our experiment are inspired by [27, 13], the number of total clients, number of clients participates per FL round, and the specific choices of E𝐸E for various datasets in our experiment are summarized in Table 1.
For Task 1, 2, and 3, our FL process starts from a VGG-9 model with 77.68%percent77.6877.68\% test accuracy, a LeNet model with 88%percent8888\% accuracy, and a VGG-11 model with 69.02%percent69.0269.02\% top-1 accuracy respectively and for Sentiment140, Reddit datasets FL process starts with models having test accuracy 75%percent7575\% and 18.8618.8618.86 respectively.

Blackbox: we assume the attacker does not have any extra access to the FL process. Thus, for the blackbox attacking scheme, the attacker trains over 𝒟edgesubscript𝒟edge\mathcal{D}_{\text{edge}} using the same hyper-parameters (including learning rate schedules, number of local epochs, etc as shown in Table 1) as other honest clients for all tasks; (ii) PGD without replacement: since we assume it is a whitebox attack, the attacker can use different hyper-parameters from honest clients. For Task 1, the attacker trains over 𝒟edgesubscript𝒟edge\mathcal{D}_{\text{edge}} projecting onto an ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} ball of radius ε=2𝜀2\varepsilon=2. However, in defending against Krum, Multi-Krum, and RFA, we found that this choice of ε𝜀\varepsilon fails to pass the defenses. Thus we shrink ε𝜀\varepsilon to hide among the updates of honest clients. Additionally, we also decay the ε𝜀\varepsilon value during the training process and we observe that it helps to hide the attack better. Empirically, we found that ε=0.5×0.998t,1.5×0.998t𝜀0.5superscript0.998𝑡1.5superscript0.998𝑡\varepsilon=0.5\times 0.998^{t},1.5\times 0.998^{t} works best. We also note that rather than locally projecting at every SGD step, including a projection only once every 101010 SGD steps leads to better performance. For Task 2 we use a setup similar to the one above except that we set ε=1.5𝜀1.5\varepsilon=1.5 while defending against NDC and ε=1𝜀1\varepsilon=1 for Krum, Multi-Krum, and RFA. For Task 4 we use fixed ε=1.0𝜀1.0\varepsilon=1.0 which lets it pass all defenses. (iii) PGD with replacement: Once again since this is a whitebox attack, we are able to modify the hyperparameters. Since the adversary scales its model up before sending it back to the PS, we shrink ε𝜀\varepsilon apriori so that it is small enough to pass the defenses even after scaling. For Task 1, we use ε=0.1𝜀0.1\varepsilon=0.1 for NDC and ε=0.083𝜀0.083\varepsilon=0.083 for the remaining defenses. For Task 2, we use ε=0.3𝜀0.3\varepsilon=0.3 for NDC and ε=0.25𝜀0.25\varepsilon=0.25 for the remaining defenses. The rate of decay of ε𝜀\varepsilon remains the same across experiments. For Task 4 we use a fixed ε=0.01𝜀0.01\varepsilon=0.01 and the attacker uses adaptive learning rate =0.001×0.998tabsent0.001superscript0.998𝑡=0.001\times 0.998^{t} for epoch t𝑡t.

references: We used a 999-layer VGG style network architecture (VGG-9). Details of our VGG-9 architecture is shown in Table 2. Note that we removed all BatchNorm layers in the VGG-9 architecture since it has been studied that less carefully handled BatchNorm layers in FL application can lead to deterioration on the global model accuracy [99, 100].
